questions.text:
A problem with minimizing a function

I have the following cost function:

\mbox{BSP Cost}=\sum_{i=1}^{\frac{n}{G}}G^{2}\left\lceil \frac{i}{p}\right\rceil +g\left(p\right)\sum_{i=1}^{\frac{n}{G}}Gi+l\left(p\right)\frac{n}{G}

I would like to minimize it by choosing an appropriate G (i.e., G is a function of p and n). I have simplified it to the following form:

\mbox{BSP Cost}=\frac{Gn}{2p}+\frac{n^{2}}{2p}+g\left(p\right)\cdot\left(\frac{n}{2G}+\frac{n^{2}}{2G^{2}}\right)+l\left(p\right)\frac{n}{G}\to\min

To find the minimization, I used a derivative \frac{d}{dG} on the cost function, and compared to zero. I got this:

\frac{nG^{3}-g\left(p\right)npG-g\left(p\right)n^{2}p-2l\left(p\right)npG}{2pG^{3}}=0

nG^{3}-g\left(p\right)npG-g\left(p\right)np-2l\left(p\right)npG=0

And I'm not sure how to proceed from this point. Can you help me find a function for G(n,p)? If you see any mistakes in the process above, please tell me.

EDIT: it might also be important to mention that all the variables and functions (g,n,p,l,G) are positive.

EDIT 2: an rough approximation formula will do!

EDIT 3: Here's an approximation of g,l:

g\left(p\right)=-0.858p^{3}+12.31p^{2}-47.12p+79.67

l\left(p\right)=670.9p^{2}+2815p-2763

My approach was to use the following formula: \frac1{1-r} where r is the common ratio. In the end I got 2/3. Am I correct?

questions.text:
showing a set is totally disconnected

So, we are considering the subset

S = \{(x, y) \in \mathbb{R^2} | (x \text{ and } y \in \mathbb{Q}) \text{ or } (x \text{ and } y \notin \mathbb{Q})\}

And consider its complement T = \mathbb{R^2} \backslash S

The set T is disconnected, actually I am fairly certain it is totally disconnected. I am just having problems showing that rigorously. I was trying to show it using straight lines but I don't think I was getting anywhere. I know that a totally disconnected set's only connected sets are the one point sets. I've been trying to show that given two arbitrary points, that a separation exists between them. It is more difficult since this is in the plane.

Any hints at all would be a great help. Maybe I'm making mountains of molehills.

questions.text_natural_language:
showing a set is totally disconnected

So, we're looking at this subset which contains all points (x,y) in the plane where either both x and y are rational numbers, or both x and y are irrational numbers.

And we're considering the complement of this set - that is, all the points where one coordinate is rational and the other is irrational.

I think this complement set T is totally disconnected, meaning that you can't connect any two different points in it with a continuous path that stays entirely within the set. But I'm having trouble proving this rigorously. I tried using straight lines but that didn't work. I know that for a totally disconnected set, the only connected pieces are individual points. I've been trying to show that for any two points, you can separate them somehow. It's harder because we're working in the plane instead of just on a line.

Any hints would be really helpful. Maybe I'm making this more complicated than it needs to be.

What is the intuition behind this definition?

questions.text:
Mean value theorem and a strictly increasing, positive second derivative

Let f(x) be two times differentiable in [a, b]. The Mean Value Theorem tells us that there's such a point a\lt c\lt b, such that {f}'(c)=\frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}.

If \forall x \in [a, b], {f}''(x)\gt 0 and f''(x) is strictly increasing then c\gt \frac{a+b}{2}.

I'm having a hard time figuring this one out. More so, I can't seem to understand why this is true, intuitively.

I tried the following: Write f(x) Taylor's expansion of degree 1, around a. Then, for x=b we get: f(b)-f(a)=f'(a)(b-a)+\frac{1}{2}f''(\xi)(b-a)^2 \implies f'(c)=f'(a)+\frac{1}{2}f''(\xi)(b-a)

Now I still haven't used the fact that f''(x) is positive and strictly increasing in [a, b] (which btw also implies that f'(x) is strictly increasing). I tried playing with the expression above but I just don't see which direction to go.

Please don't give a full solution. Hints and intuition are appreciated.

questions.text_natural_language:
Mean value theorem and a strictly increasing, positive second derivative

Let f of x be two times differentiable in the interval from a to b. The Mean Value Theorem tells us that there's such a point where a is less than c which is less than b, such that f prime of c equals f of b minus f of a all divided by b minus a.

If for all x in the interval from a to b, the second derivative of f at x is greater than zero and the second derivative of f at x is strictly increasing then c is greater than a plus b divided by two.

I'm having a hard time figuring this one out. More so, I can't seem to understand why this is true, intuitively.

I tried the following: Write f of x using Taylor's expansion of degree 1, around a. Then, for x equals b we get: f of b minus f of a equals f prime of a times b minus a plus one half times f double prime of xi times b minus a squared which implies f prime of c equals f prime of a plus one half times f double prime of xi times b minus a

Now I still haven't used the fact that the second derivative of f at x is positive and strictly increasing in the interval from a to b (which by the way also implies that the first derivative of f at x is strictly increasing). I tried playing with the expression above but I just don't see which direction to go.

Please don't give a full solution. Hints and intuition are appreciated.

questions.text:
Analytic Geometry | Two Planes and a Angle | Two Solutions

This is me again, I have another problem which I haven't been able to solve, the legend goes like this:
Find the equation of the plane that contains the points P_1(1,0,-1), P_2(2,0,2) and forms a 600 (\theta) angle with the other plane 2x-2y+z+6=0 (Two Solutions).

Here's what I've done:

Since we already know two points, P1(1, 0, -1) and P2(2,0,2) they both satisfy a planes equation:
Ax+By+Cz+D=0 So, we substitute x,y,z respectively for each point, giving use these two equations

  1. A(1)+B(0)+C(-1)+D=0
  2. A(2)+B(0)+C(2)+D=0

Simplifying we get:

  1. A-C+D=0
  2. 2A+2C+D=0

Now, according to the following theorem the angle that is formed by the perpendiculars of to planes is the following:

\cos{\theta} = \pm \frac{AA'+BB'+CC'}{\sqrt{A^2+B^2+C^2} \sqrt{(A')^2+(B')^2+(C')^2}} Where [A,B,C] Are the director numbers of the normal in the first plane and [A',B',C'] Are the director numbers of the normal in the second plane.

Now, given those and taking the known angle of 60o, we substitute the director numbers of 2x-2y+z+6-0:[A'=2,B'=-2,C'=1] and the angle in the last formula, giving us: \cos{60^\circ} = \pm \frac{A(2)-B(-2)+C(1)}{\sqrt{A^2+B^2+C^2} \sqrt{(2)^2+(-2)^2+(1)^2}}

Simplifying, we get(positive because \theta is acute): \frac{1}{2}=\frac{2A-2B+C}{3 \sqrt{A^2+B^2+C^2}}

Another simplification finally for: 3(A^2+B^2+C^2)=(4A-4B+2C)^2 Now, we have 3 equations:

  1. A-C+D=0
  2. 2A+2C+D=0
  3. 3(A^2+B^2+C^2)=(4A-4B+2C)^2

If we take 1) and 2) and write them as D(A,C) we get:

  1. D=C-A
  2. D=-2A-2C

From which we can obtain A in terms of C -2A-2C=C-A A=-3C Now we substitute back in 1): (-3C)-C+D=0 C=\frac{1}{4}D Since I want every director number in terms of D we substitute again but in A since A was in function of C. A=-3C A=-3(\frac{1}{4}D) A=\frac{-3}{4}D

Now, we have found A(D), C(D) we have yet to find B(D) I'll explain why I think and want everything in terms of D, if we take the general form of a planes equation Ax+By+Cz+D=0 and substitute A and C with our known values we get: (\frac{-3}{4}D)x+By+(\frac{1}{4}D)z+D=0 if we divide by D \neq 0 and then multiply by 4 to eliminate fractions: \frac{-3}{4}x+\frac{B}{D}y+\frac{1}{4}z+1=0 -3x+\frac{4B}{D}y+z+4=0 From here it's clear that if we find B in terms of D and B is linear we have the planes equation, so, in 3) 3(A^2+B^2+C^2)=(4A-4B+2C)^2 we substitute A and C: 3((\frac{-3}{4}D)^2+B^2+(\frac{1}{4}D)^2)=(4(\frac{-3}{4})-4B+2(\frac{1}{4}D))^2 \vdots 104B^2+80DB+35D^2=0

Here is were I get stuck, I get imaginary parts, since I have to use the quadratic formula, so any help is really appreciated, the problem states that there are two solutions, but this is what I have thought of if anyone can supply any solution I'll be very grateful.

Regards.. Tristian

questions.text_natural_language:
Geometry problem about planes and angles

I'm working on a problem where I need to find the equation of a plane. The plane has to go through two specific points: one at coordinates (1,0,-1) and another at (2,0,2). Also, this plane needs to make a sixty degree angle with another plane whose equation is 2x minus 2y plus z plus 6 equals zero.

I started by using the general plane equation Ax plus By plus Cz plus D equals zero, and substituted my two points to get two equations. Then I used the formula for the angle between two planes, which involves the dot product of their normal vectors divided by the product of their magnitudes.

When I work through all the algebra, I end up with a quadratic equation that gives me complex numbers when I try to solve it. But the problem says there should be two real solutions. I'm not sure where I went wrong.

Can someone help me figure out what I'm missing?

questions.text:
Lower Bound of a Coefficient

Fix \epsilon >0. Suppose p_{n}(z) = z^{n}+a_{n-1}z^{n-1}+ \cdots + a_{0} \in \mathbb{Z}[x] is irreducible and has all positive real roots. Show that independently of n except for finitely many explicitly computable exceptions that |a_{n-1}| \geq (2-\epsilon)n.

The sum of the roots is -\frac{a_{n-1}}{a_n} which is -a_{n-1}. So -a_{n-1} >0 which means that a_{n-1} \leq 0. So |a_{n-1}| = -a_{n-1}. The problem can then be rephrased as follows: Show that the sum of the roots of the above polynomial is \geq (2-\epsilon)n. Could we use a proof by contradiction? I think irreducibility is an important property here.

Source: Computational excursions in analysis and number theory by P Borwein

Using the fundamental theorem, the sum of zeros is given by -ck-11, which equals -ck-1. Since all zeros are positive, we must have -ck-1>0, hence ck-1<0. This gives us |ck-1|=-ck-1. questions.text_natural_language:
Finding a Lower Bound for a Polynomial Coefficient

Let's fix some small positive number epsilon greater than zero. Now suppose we have a polynomial p of degree n in the variable z, where p(z) equals z to the power n, plus a coefficient times z to the power (n minus 1), plus dots indicating more terms, plus the constant term a_0, and this polynomial has integer coefficients. We assume this polynomial is irreducible and has all positive real roots. We want to show that for all n except finitely many computable exceptions, the absolute value of the coefficient of z to the power (n minus 1) is at least (2 minus epsilon) times n.

Now, from Vieta's formulas, we know that the sum of all the roots equals negative the coefficient of z to the power (n minus 1) divided by the leading coefficient, which is just negative a_(n minus 1) since the leading coefficient is 1. So the sum of roots equals negative a_(n minus 1). Since all roots are positive, this sum must be positive, which means negative a_(n minus 1) is greater than zero, so a_(n minus 1) must be less than or equal to zero. Therefore, the absolute value of a_(n minus 1) equals negative a_(n minus 1). The problem can be restated as: show that the sum of the roots of our polynomial is at least (2 minus epsilon) times n. Maybe we could use proof by contradiction? I think the irreducibility property is key here.

Source: Computational excursions in analysis and number theory by P Borwein
